Award.AwardTitle: Mechanics in Photopolymerization Based Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing, often called 3D printing, is poised to revolutionize manufacturing. Its transformation into a manufacturing platform requires the ability to reliably create shape as well as desirable properties. Currently there is little understanding on how the mechanical properties of 3D printed parts relate to the printing process. This award supports fundamental research on mechanics of the layer-by-layer photopolymerization process common to many 3D printing system. It provides knowledge on how mechanical properties of the printed materials emerge from the printing process and how distortions occur. The knowledge gained provides solutions to the selection of printing parameters that yield parts with desirable properties. Such knowledge will enhance the use of photopolymerization based additive manufacturing for a wide variety of applications in healthcare, biomedical, aerospace, and automotive industries. This research involves several disciplines including mechanics, physics, chemistry, manufacturing, and materials science. The associated activities include underrepresented groups in the multidisciplinary research.

In photopolymerization based additive manufacturing there exist strong interactions of optical absorption, chemical reaction, species diffusion, phase change and volume shrinkage. Consequently, the layered deposition processes result in a material with dramatically different mechanical properties than the same polymer processed in bulk. This award supports research to investigate the relationship between print parameters and resulting product characteristics. The outcomes will bridge the knowledge gap between the printing process and the geometry and properties of the printed part. The research team will perform experiments to systematically investigate mechanical properties of the material within the printed layers and of the interfaces. The experimental observation will facilitate the establishment of theories and computational models. These models are defined in the context of continuum mechanics considering not only stress and strain but also the printing conditions and chemical processes. The computational models will be used to conduct parametric study to identify optimized printing parameters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objectives of this project are to study the mechanics and evolution of mechanical properties of polymers in photopolymerization during 3D printing and to establish a simulation framework of the layer-by-layer 3D printing process.

This project developed fundamental understandings how properties of a polymer change during the photopolymerization which is one of the commonly used mechanisms in 3D printing and established several innovative polymer systems nd methods for 3D printing. First, this project gained the understandings of the evolution of mechanical properties of photopolymer during the photocuring process. These understandings led to the development of a material model to predict the dramatic property change of the polymer when a UV light is irradiated on the polymer resin. Second, the new material model was further used to establish a numerical model framework that simulates the photopolymer 3D printing process, in which the change of polymer properties can affect the shape and quality of printed parts. This numerical model framework can then be used to study how printing parameters, such as light brightness, light exposure time, and layer thickness can be optimized to obtain parts with improved shape and quality control. Third, based on the new understandings, a new method of using light brightness and property evolution to achieve controllable deformation of the printed thin part was developed. This method can be used to print a thin sheet that can fold into complicated 3D structures after printing. Fourth, a new two-stage curing method was developed, in which the polymer resin is first photocured to form a shape and then is thermally cured to improve the mechanical properties. This new method allows 3D printing high-performance engineering polymers, such as epoxy, which cannot be printed previously. Lastly, a new method of 3D printing functionally graded materials was developed. In this method, both light brightness and the two-stage curing were used to print part whose properties can vary dramatically from one region to another region with precise control within the part. This new method greatly expanded the design space and application scope of 3D printing in functional structures and devices.

The fundamental understandings and the new methods developed in this project are applicable for 3D printing parts with better property and shape control. They also dramatically expand the types of materials that can be 3D printed. 3D printing of polymers is often frustrated by the lack of consistency in material properties and shape distortions. This is generally solved by using the trial-and-error approach, which is very time consuming and expensive. The numerical simulation framework that was developed based on the fundamental understandings allows a user to simulate the printing process with different printing parameters then to use the best parameters to print the part. This will save time as well as reduce the cost. Another limitation in 3D printing of polymers is the lack of materials that can be printed. The methods developed in this project allow printing of a suite of new materials. These include materials that allow shapeshifting after printing, which can be used for 3D printed electronics; materials that have the properties close to engineering polymers, which has the potential for direct 3D printing engineering parts; and functionally graded materials that can be used for functional materials and structures, such as energy absorption materials and pre-surgical planning models. This project also provided learning opportunities for students at both graduate and undergraduate levels. Undergraduate students from the underrepresented group were involved in this project by participating in research directly. Middle school teachers also participated in summer research and passed the excitement on 3D printing research to local middle schools.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Images (1 of )
  • The grayscale-DLP (g-DLP) 3D printing of functionally graded material via two-stage curing. a) a schematics graph to show the g-DLP printing of graded material via a two-stage curing process. b) a 3D lattice metamaterial shows sequential deformation.
    Xiao Kuang
    Public Domain
    Hang (Jerry) Qi
    The grayscale-DLP 3D printing of functionally graded material
  • Fabrication of origami structures by two-sides illuminations. a) Schematic process of two-sides illumination method. Printed structures: b) a table, c) a miura structure, d) a tent, and e) a crane.
    Zeang Zhao
    Public Domain
    Hang (Jerry) Qi
    Fabrication of origami structures by two-sides illuminations.
  • Desolvation induced reversible origami folding. a) A schematic graph of grayscale photo-printing, desolvation induced self-folding and swelling induced shape recovery. B) Examples of origami shapes. c) The method is used for 3D electronics.
    Zeang Zhao
    Public Domain
    Hang (Jerry) Qi
    Desolvation induced reversible origami folding
  • Continuous liquid interface production (CLIP) assisted digit light processing (DLP) 3D printing of high performance epoxy via two-stage curing. a) A schematic graph of printing and the second stage curing. Examples of printed parts: b) a lattice ball, c) a gear, and d) a screw-nut set.
    Xiao Kuang
    Public Domain
    Hang (Jerry) Qi
    Continuous liquid interface production assisted digit light processing 3D printing of high performance epoxy
  • Direct ink write (DIW) based 3D printing using two-stage curing. a) a schematic illustration of the 3D printing epoxy composite material. Photographs of epoxy parts: b) a square-shaped lattice structure, c) a gear, d) a spiral swirl bowl, and e) a 3-links trophy. Scale bars in b-e are 6 mm).
    Kaijuan Chen
    Public Domain
    Hang (Jerry) Qi
    Direct ink write (DIW) based 3D printing using two-stage curing
  • Encryption via diffusion assisted coloring for graded materials. a) A wo-stage cured film with grayscale pattern. b) A dye or c) solution to visualize the grayscale pattern by UV light and visible light, respectively. d) Coloring kinetics of the film. g) A name card. Scale bars: 5 mm.
    Xiao Kuang
    Public Domain
    Hang (Jerry) Qi
    Encryption via diffusion assisted coloring for graded materials
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research objectives of this project are to study the mechanics and evolution of mechanical properties of polymers in photopolymerization during 3D printing and to establish a simulation framework of the layer-by-layer 3D printing process. This project developed fundamental understandings how properties of a polymer change during the photopolymerization which is one of the commonly used mechanisms in 3D printing and established several innovative polymer systems nd methods for 3D printing. First, this project gained the understandings of the evolution of mechanical properties of photopolymer during the photocuring process. These understandings led to the development of a material model to predict the dramatic property change of the polymer when a UV light is irradiated on the polymer resin. Second, the new material model was further used to establish a numerical model framework that simulates the photopolymer 3D printing process, in which the change of polymer properties can affect the shape and quality of printed parts. This numerical model framework can then be used to study how printing parameters, such as light brightness, light exposure time, and layer thickness can be optimized to obtain parts with improved shape and quality control. Third, based on the new understandings, a new method of using light brightness and property evolution to achieve controllable deformation of the printed thin part was developed. This method can be used to print a thin sheet that can fold into complicated 3D structures after printing. Fourth, a new two-stage curing method was developed, in which the polymer resin is first photocured to form a shape and then is thermally cured to improve the mechanical properties. This new method allows 3D printing high-performance engineering polymers, such as epoxy, which cannot be printed previously. Lastly, a new method of 3D printing functionally graded materials was developed. In this method, both light brightness and the two-stage curing were used to print part whose properties can vary dramatically from one region to another region with precise control within the part. This new method greatly expanded the design space and application scope of 3D printing in functional structures and devices. The fundamental understandings and the new methods developed in this project are applicable for 3D printing parts with better property and shape control. They also dramatically expand the types of materials that can be 3D printed. 3D printing of polymers is often frustrated by the lack of consistency in material properties and shape distortions. This is generally solved by using the trial-and-error approach, which is very time consuming and expensive. The numerical simulation framework that was developed based on the fundamental understandings allows a user to simulate the printing process with different printing parameters then to use the best parameters to print the part. This will save time as well as reduce the cost. Another limitation in 3D printing of polymers is the lack of materials that can be printed. The methods developed in this project allow printing of a suite of new materials. These include materials that allow shapeshifting after printing, which can be used for 3D printed electronics; materials that have the properties close to engineering polymers, which has the potential for direct 3D printing engineering parts; and functionally graded materials that can be used for functional materials and structures, such as energy absorption materials and pre-surgical planning models. This project also provided learning opportunities for students at both graduate and undergraduate levels. Undergraduate students from the underrepresented group were involved in this project by participating in research directly. Middle school teachers also participated in summer research and passed the excitement on 3D printing research to local middle schools.
